ai-dn17:2.4.2_0: He meditated spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-dn17:2.4.2_1: likewise the second (direction), third (direction) and fourth (direction).
ai-dn17:2.4.2_2: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-dn17:2.4.5_0: He meditated spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.

ai-dn17:2.5.1_0: King Mahāsudassana had 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.2_0: He had 84,000 palaces, with the Palace of Principle foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.3_0: He had 84,000 chambers, with the great foyer foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.4_0: He had 84,000 couches made of gold, silver, ivory, and hardwood. They were spread with woollen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends.
ai-dn17:2.5.5_0: He had 84,000 bull elephants with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the royal bull elephant named Sabbath foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.6_0: He had 84,000 horses with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the royal steed named Thundercloud foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.7_0: He had 84,000 chariots upholstered with the hide of lions, tigers, and leopards, and cream rugs, with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the chariot named Triumph foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.8_0: He had 84,000 treasures, with the jewel-treasure foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.9_0: He had 84,000 women, with Queen Subhaddā foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.10_0: He had 84,000 householders, with the householder-treasure foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.11_0: He had 84,000 aristocrat vassals, with the counselor-treasure foremost.
ai-dn17:2.5.12_0: He had 84,000 milk-cows with silken reins and bronze pails.
ai-dn17:2.5.13_0: He had 8,400,000 fine cloths of linen, cotton, silk, and wool.
ai-dn17:2.5.14_0: He had 84,000 servings of food, which were presented to him as offerings in the morning and evening.
ai-dn17:2.6.1_0: Now at that time his 84,000 royal elephants came to attend on him in the morning and evening.
ai-dn17:2.6.3_0: ‘What if instead half of the elephants took turns to attend on me at the end of each century?’
ai-dn17:2.6.4_0: He instructed the counselor-treasure to do this, and so it was done.
ai-dn17:2.6.5_0: ‘Then listener is there 84,000 bull elephants to attend on me. What is that one hundred years old? And that was how two thousand years old age appeared to me?’
ai-dn17:2.6.7_0: After some time King Mahāsudassana had passed, when two hundred years had passed, King Mahāsudassana waited for a hundred years and forty thousand years.
ai-dn17:2.7.1_0: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, Queen Subhaddā thought,
ai-dn17:2.7.2_0: ‘It is long since I have seen the king.
ai-dn17:2.7.2_1: Why don’t I go to see him?’
ai-dn17:2.7.3_0: Then Queen Subhaddā addressed the harem,
ai-dn17:2.7.4_0: ‘Come, bathe your heads and dress in yellow.
ai-dn17:2.7.5_0: It is long since we saw the king, and we shall go to see him.’
ai-dn17:2.7.6_0: ‘Yes, ma’am,’ replied the ladies of the harem. They did as she asked and returned to the queen.
ai-dn17:2.8.1_0: Then Queen Subhaddā addressed the counselor,
ai-dn17:2.8.2_0: ‘Dear counselor-treasure, please ready the army of four divisions. It is long since we saw the king, and we shall go to see him.’
ai-dn17:2.8.3_0: ‘Yes, my queen,’ he replied, and did as he was asked. He informed the queen,
ai-dn17:2.8.4_0: ‘Dear Queen Bhaddā’s army is four divisions.
ai-dn17:2.8.6_0: Then Queen Subhaddā together with the ladies of the harem went with the army to the Palace of Principle.
ai-dn17:2.8.6_1: After approaching the Dhamma, he went to the great foyer,
ai-dn17:2.8.7_0: where she stood leaning against a door-post.
ai-dn17:2.8.9_0: ‘What’s that, it sounds like a big crowd!’ Coming out of the foyer he saw Queen Subhaddā leaning against a door-post and said to her,
ai-dn17:2.8.10_0: ‘Please stay there, my queen, don’t enter in here.’
ai-dn17:2.9.2_0: ‘Come, mister, bring the golden couch from the great foyer and set it up in the golden palm grove.’
ai-dn17:2.9.3_0: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied, and did as he was asked.
ai-dn17:2.9.4_0: The king laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.

ai-dn17:2.13.1_0: Not long after that, King Mahāsudassana passed away.
ai-dn17:2.13.2_0: It’s like that householder or their child have finished eating the meal and refused an invitation to eat more.
ai-dn17:2.13.2_1: so too,t King Mahāsudassana had feelings.
ai-dn17:2.13.3_0: When he passed away King Mahāsudassana was reborn in a good place, a Brahmā realm.
ai-dn17:2.13.4_0: Ānanda, King Mahāsudassana played children’s games for 84,000 years.
ai-dn17:2.13.5_0: He ruled as viceroy for 84,000 years.
ai-dn17:2.13.6_0: He ruled as sovereign lord over the kingdom.
ai-dn17:2.13.7_0: He led the spiritual life as a layman in the Palace of Principle for 84,000 years.
ai-dn17:2.13.8_0: And having developed the four Brahmā meditations, when his body broke up, after death, Makhādeva’s son was reborn in a good place, a Brahmā realm.
ai-dn17:2.14.2_0: ‘Surely King Mahāsudassana must have been someone else at that time?’
ai-dn17:2.14.3_0: But that’s how the king should be seen, at that time King Mahāsudassana.
ai-dn17:2.14.4_0: Mine were the 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost. And mine were all the other possessions.
ai-dn17:2.15.1_0: Of those 84,000 cities, I only stayed in one, the capital Kusāvatī.
ai-dn17:2.15.2_0: Of those 84,000 mansions, I only dwelt in one, the Palace of Principle.
ai-dn17:2.15.3_0: Of those 84,000 chambers, I only dwelt in the great foyer.
ai-dn17:2.15.4_0: Of those 84,000 couches, I only used one, made of gold or silver or ivory or heartwood.
ai-dn17:2.15.5_0: Of those 84,000 bull elephants, I only rode one, the royal bull elephant named Sabbath.
ai-dn17:2.15.6_0: Of those 84,000 horses, I only rode one, the royal horse named Thundercloud.
ai-dn17:2.15.7_0: Of those 84,000 chariots, I only rode one, the chariot named Triumph.
ai-dn17:2.15.8_0: Of those 84,000 women, I was only served by one, a maiden of the aristocratic or merchant classes.
ai-dn17:2.15.9_0: Of those 8,400,000,000 cloths, I only wore one pair, made of fine linen, cotton, silk, and wool.
ai-dn17:2.15.10_0: Of those 84,000 servings of food, I only had one, eating at most a serving of rice and suitable sauce.
ai-dn17:2.16.1_0: See, Ānanda! All those conditioned phenomena have passed, ceased, and perished.
ai-dn17:2.16.5_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-dn17:2.17.1_0: I recall having set aside six times the body, King A wheel-turning monarch.
ai-dn17:2.17.2_0: But Ānanda, I do not see any place in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans where the Realized One would lay down his body for the eighth time.”
ai-dn17:2.17.3_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-dn17:2.17.4_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-dn17:2.17.9_0: The fourth Discourse about Mahāsudassana is finished.
